prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: T Cha: C2H(3-2) & HCN(3-2)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observe C2H(3-2), HCN(3-2), and adjacent continuum emission from T Cha in Band 6 using the C36-4 configuration to achieve 0.3" resolution imaging.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our Band 6 correlator setup for C2H(3-2) is driven by the goal to obtain complete coverage of the hyperfine transition sequence from 262.004 to 262.209 GHz -- so as to perform C2H excitation analysis (see Kastner et al. 2014) -- with spectral resolution sufficient to easily resolve the 8 km/s linewidths of T Cha. We hence center on the 262.051 GHz hyperfine transition and choose the 937.5 MHz bandwidth, which provides velocity resolution of 0.6 km/s. The C2H(3-2) upper sideband setup conveniently includes HCN(3-2), which we will observe at higher spectral resolution (since the hyperfine splitting is minimal). We also include two continuum basebands in the lower sideband.

Our goal is to establish the inner & outer C2H emitting region radii and morphology of the T Cha disk. Based on interferometric measurements of C2H & CO in the TW Hya disk, and the similar physical scale of the T Cha CO disk -- see Figs 1 & 3 in proposal -- we expect inner & outer C2H ring diameters of ~100/240 AU (~1"/2.4") for T Cha. The 0.3" resolution and 4" largest angular scale of C36-4 at 260 GHz (Band 6) is hence optimium for our science goals (see Fig 4 in proposal).

For T Cha & V4046 Sgr, the CN(2-1) line fluxes (integrated over the main hyperfine lines) are 2.4 Jy km/s (extrapolated from the 3-2 line flux of 3.7 Jy km/s; Sacco et al. 2014) and 20 Jy km/s (Kastner et al. 2008, 2014). The integrated SMA-measured C2H(3-2) line flux of V4046 Sgr is ~10 Jy km/s (Qi et al., unpublished). T Cha has yet to be measured in C2H emission, but is very similar to TW Hya & V4046 Sgr in terms of its HCO+/CO, CN/CO, and HCN/CO line ratios (Sacco et al. 2014). Hence, adopting the measured CN/C2H line ratio for V4046 Sgr, we predict a C2H(3-2) line flux of ~1.2 Jy km/s for T Cha. The linewidth of T Cha is ~8 km/s, so the estimated mean C2H line flux density is 0.15 Jy. For the (expected) ~1" outer C2H radius, and resolution of 0.3" (see below), we therefore predict mean line fluxes per beam of 15 mJy for T Cha. Our target rms sensitivity of 3 mJy will hence ensure a 5-sigma measurement (per beam) across much of the C2H line image.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: T Cha: CN(2-1) & CO(2-1)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observe CN(2-1), CO(2-1), and adjacent continuum emission from T Cha in Band 6 using the C36-4 configuration to achieve 0.3" resolution imaging.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: As for Science Goal 1 (C2H), our Band 6 correlator setup for CN(2-1) is driven by the goal to obtain complete coverage of the hyperfine transition sequence (from 226.342 to 226.892 GHz), both to obtain a complete flux measurement and to perform excitation analysis. Hence, analogous to our C2H setup, we center on the 262.617 GHz transition and choose the 937.5 MHz bandwidth. The CN(2-1) upper sideband setup conveniently includes CO(2-1), which will provide a valuable morphological comparison. We also include two continuum basebands in the lower sideband.
As we seek to directly compare the disk CN and C2H morphologies, our justification for the angular resolution and largest angular scale provided by C36-4 is the same as in Science Goal 1.

For T Cha, the CN(2-1) line flux (integrated over the main hyperfine lines) is 2.4 Jy km/s (extrapolated from the 3-2 line flux of 3.7 Jy km/s; Sacco et al. 2014). The T Cha linewidth is ~8 km/s, so the estimated mean CN line flux density is 0.3 Jy. Adopting the same source region spatial scale as for C2H, we hence predict a mean line flux per beam of 30 mJy. Our target rms sensitivity of 5 mJy is then chosen to ensure 5-sigma measurements per beam across most of the CN line image.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: V4046 Sgr: C2H(3-2) & HCN(3-2)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observe C2H(3-2), HCN(3-2), and adjacent continuum emission from V4046 Sgr in Band 6 using the C36-4 configuration to achieve 0.3" resolution imaging.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our Band 6 correlator setup for C2H(3-2) is driven by the goal to obtain complete coverage of the hyperfine transition sequence from 262.004 to 262.209 GHz -- so as to perform C2H excitation analysis (see Kastner et al. 2014) -- with spectral resolution sufficient to easily resolve the lines (linewidth of 5 km/s for V4046 Sgr). We hence center on the 262.051 GHz hyperfine transition and choose the 937.5 MHz bandwidth, which provides velocity resolution of 0.6 km/s. The C2H(3-2) upper sideband setup conveniently includes HCN(3-2), which we will observe at higher spectral resolution (since the hyperfine splitting is minimal). We also include two continuum basebands in the lower sideband.

Our goal is to establish the inner & outer C2H emitting region radii and morphology of the V4046 Sgr disk. Based on previous interferometric measurements of disk C2H -- see Fig 3 in proposal -- we expect inner/outer C2H ring diameters of 150/400 AU (~2"/5") for V4046 Sgr. The 0.3" resolution and 4" largest angular scale of C36-4 at 260 GHz (Band 6) is hence optimium for our science goals (see Fig 4 in proposal).

The integrated SMA-measured C2H(3-2) line flux of V4046 Sgr is ~10 Jy km/s (Qi et al., unpublished), and the linewidth is ~5 km/s, so the estimated mean C2H line flux density is ~2.0 Jy. For the (measured) ~3" outer C2H radius and resolution of 0.3" (see below), we therefore predict a mean line flux per beam of 20 mJy. Our target rms sensitivity of 4 mJy will hence ensure 5-sigma detections (per beam) across most of the C2H line images.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: V4046 Sgr: CN(2-1) & CO(2-1)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observe CN(2-1), CO(2-1), and adjacent continuum emission from V4046 Sgr in Band 6 using the C36-4 configuration to achieve 0.3" resolution imaging.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: As for Science Goal 3 (C2H), our Band 6 correlator setup for CN(2-1) is driven by the goal to obtain complete coverage of the hyperfine transition sequence (from 226.342 to 226.892 GHz), both to obtain a complete flux measurement and to perform excitation analysis. Hence, analogous to our C2H setup, we center on the 262.617 GHz transition and choose the 937.5 MHz bandwidth. The CN(2-1) upper sideband setup conveniently includes CO(2-1), which will provide a valuable morphological comparison. We also include two continuum basebands in the lower sideband.
As we seek to directly compare the disk CN and C2H morphologies, our justification for the angular resolution and largest angular scale provided by C36-4 is the same as in Science Goal 3.

For V4046 Sgr, the CN(2-1) line flux (integrated over the main hyperfine lines) is 20 Jy km/s (Kastner et al. 2008) and the linewidth is ~5 km/s, so the estimated mean CN line flux density is ~4.0 Jy. Adopting the same source region spatial scale as for C2H, we hence predict mean a line flux per beam of 40 mJy. Our target rms sensitivity of 7 mJy is then chosen to ensure 5-sigma measurements per beam across most of the CN line image.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The powerful high-energy radiation fields characteristic of young,solar-mass stars should be of fundamental importance in determining the timescale over which, and the conditions out of which, exoplanets and their atmospheres emerge. However, observational evidence of the consequences of such stellar irradiation on outer disk regions remains elusive. We propose to obtain subarcsecond ALMA observations of C2H, CN, and HCN in the molecular disks orbiting the nearby, young solar analogs V4046 Sgr and T Cha. We will take advantage of the large angular radii and contrasting inclinations of the V4046 Sgr and T Cha disks --- both of which may already harbor young planets --- to establish the radial and vertical distributions of these potential molecular tracers of disk irradiation and gas-grain processes. The results will provide much-needed constraints on models for the production of dissociation products within molecular disks, by establishing whether the abundances of C2H and CN are enhanced in disk surface layers that are readily exposed to stellar UV and X-ray emission, or are instead generated deep within the disk, via pure gas-phase and/or gas-grain processes.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Chester F. Carlson Center for Imaging, Rochester Institute of Technology
